articles.headline: The Economic Growth That Experts Can’t Count
articles.snippet: A fixation on standard (and lately sluggish) measures of growth may obscure more profound advances in the nation’s innovation and well-being.
articles.abstract: A fixation on standard (and lately sluggish) measures of growth may obscure more profound advances in the nation’s innovation and well-being.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s vow to raise the annual growth rate to 4 percent has been dismissed as outlandish by economists.

articles.headline: Justice Department Urges Appeals Court to Reinstate Trump’s Travel Ban
articles.snippet: The administration said a judge’s order blocking the ban endangers national security. Opponents of the ban said it is a threat to the rule of law.
articles.abstract: The administration said a judge’s order blocking the ban endangers national security. Opponents of the ban said it is a threat to the rule of law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Monday evening urged a federal appeals court to reinstate President Trump’s targeted travel ban, saying immediate action was needed to ensure the nation’s safety.

articles.headline: A Quiet Giant of Investing Weighs In on Trump
articles.snippet: Seth Klarman is not a household name, but his letter to investors, warning about the new administration, is the most sought-after read on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Seth Klarman is not a household name, but his letter to investors, warning about the new administration, is the most sought-after read on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: He is the most successful and influential investor you have probably never heard of. His writings are so coveted and followed by Wall Street that a used copy of a book he wrote several decades ago about investing starts at $795 on Amazon, and a new copy sells for as much as $3,500.

articles.headline: During Breaks in Super Bowl, Advertisers Enter Political Debate
articles.snippet: This year, commercials with just a hint of political or social themes received an outsize response similar to the online reaction some brands have experienced since President Trump took office.
articles.abstract: This year, commercials with just a hint of political or social themes received an outsize response similar to the online reaction some brands have experienced since President Trump took office.
articles.lead_paragraph: Budweiser had a simple, noncontroversial idea for its 2017 Super Bowl ad.

articles.headline: From ‘Repeal’ to ‘Repair’: Campaign Talk on Health Law Meets Reality
articles.snippet: President Trump and his Republican allies have recast their ambitions for a rapid-fire repeal, with many lawmakers facing tough questions from constituents.
articles.abstract: President Trump and his Republican allies have recast their ambitions for a rapid-fire repeal, with many lawmakers facing tough questions from constituents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Asked at a confirmation hearing two weeks ago if he was working with President Trump on a secret plan to replace the Affordable Care Act, Representative Tom Price, Mr. Trump’s nominee for secretary of health and human services, smiled broadly and answered: “It’s true that he said that, yes.”
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Fueled by Bribes, Somalia’s Election Seen as Milestone of Corruption
articles.snippet: An estimated $20 million or more has feverishly changed hands during parliamentary elections that will culminate in the selection of the president.
articles.abstract: An estimated $20 million or more has feverishly changed hands during parliamentary elections that will culminate in the selection of the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Politicians have been peeling off wads of hundred dollar bills to buy votes. Others have shown up for parliamentary races standing next to a political nobody who was bribed or coerced into running against them, to make the race look fair. In one case, the mysterious candidate was the politician’s maid.

articles.headline: Offshore Wind Moves Into Energy’s Mainstream
articles.snippet: Offshore wind projects are luring big-name investors who are attracted to strong returns and declining costs.
articles.abstract: Offshore wind projects are luring big-name investors who are attracted to strong returns and declining costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — When engineers faced resistance from residents in Denmark over plans to build wind turbines on the Nordic country’s flat farmland, they found a better locale: the sea. The offshore wind farm, the world’s first, had just 11 turbines and could power about 3,000 homes.

articles.headline: Steve Bannon Carries Battles to Another Influential Hub: The Vatican
articles.snippet: Mr. Bannon, a Catholic, has cultivated strategic alliances with those in Rome who share his view that the pope is a dangerously misguided pontiff.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bannon, a Catholic, has cultivated strategic alliances with those in Rome who share his view that the pope is a dangerously misguided pontiff.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — When Stephen K. Bannon was still heading Breitbart News, he went to the Vatican to cover the canonization of John Paul II and make some friends. High on his list of people to meet was an archconservative American cardinal, Raymond Burke, who had openly clashed with Pope Francis.

articles.headline: They Came to Ski Idaho Slopes. Now They’re Saving the Ski Resort.
articles.snippet: Half-built when the recession hit, Tamarack fell into bankruptcy. But homeowners have banded together to buy the place, intent on ushering in better days.
articles.abstract: Half-built when the recession hit, Tamarack fell into bankruptcy. But homeowners have banded together to buy the place, intent on ushering in better days.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONNELLY, Idaho — There is an old joke in the ski industry that a resort needs to go bankrupt three times before it can be profitable. Tamarack is hoping to get away with just once.

articles.headline: How to Make America Greater: More Immigration
articles.snippet: While President Trump promises to curb immigration, research suggests a straightforward way to bulk up the economy would be to let more immigrants in.
articles.abstract: While President Trump promises to curb immigration, research suggests a straightforward way to bulk up the economy would be to let more immigrants in.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump will make America smaller.
